claim_reports.claim_text: Understanding what is making the atmosphere change is crucial for addressing climate issues.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that understanding atmospheric changes is crucial for addressing climate issues, as highlighted by NASA, Penn LPS, and the US EPA, all emphasizing the role of human activities in driving climate change.

supports.title: Evidence - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that understanding the causes of atmospheric changes, particularly human activities leading to increased greenhouse gas emissions, is crucial for addressing climate issues, as these changes are driving unprecedented warming and environmental impacts.
supports.snippet: There is unequivocal evidence that Earth is warming at an unprecedented rate. Human activity is the principal cause.

supports.title: Why it's important to learn about climate change | Penn LPS Online
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence presented in the article emphasizes the critical role of understanding human-induced changes in the atmosphere, as it highlights the unprecedented rate of climate change driven by human activities and the importance of data collection in addressing these issues.
supports.snippet: The bottom line is that no matter who you are or where you live, you cannot escape the effects of climate change. Global warming, air pollution, ...

supports.title: Basics of Climate Change | US EPA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that understanding the changes in the atmosphere, primarily due to human-induced greenhouse gas emissions, is essential for addressing climate issues, as these changes are driving unprecedented warming and environmental shifts.
supports.snippet: These changes are due to a buildup of greenhouse gases in our atmosphere and the warming of the planet due to the greenhouse effect.

unclear.title: Extreme Weather and Climate Change - NASA Science
unclear.evidence_summary: This warming affects the water cycle, shifts weather patterns, and melts land ice — all impacts that can make extreme weather worse. According ...
unclear.snippet: This warming affects the water cycle, shifts weather patterns, and melts land ice — all impacts that can make extreme weather worse. According ...

unclear.title: Climate change impacts - NOAA
unclear.evidence_summary: Climate change affects the environment in many different ways, including rising temperatures, sea level rise, drought, flooding, and more. These events affect ...
unclear.snippet: Climate change affects the environment in many different ways, including rising temperatures, sea level rise, drought, flooding, and more. These events affect ...

unclear.title: What Are the Solutions to Climate Change? - NRDC
unclear.evidence_summary: Ending our reliance on fossil fuels · Greater energy efficiency · Renewable energy · Sustainable transportation · Sustainable buildings · Better ...
unclear.snippet: Ending our reliance on fossil fuels · Greater energy efficiency · Renewable energy · Sustainable transportation · Sustainable buildings · Better ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Greenhouse gases trap heat and energy from the Sun.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that greenhouse gases trap heat and energy from the Sun, with multiple high-reliability sources explaining the greenhouse effect and its role in maintaining Earth's temperature.

supports.title: [PDF] The Greenhouse Gases
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly explains that greenhouse gases trap heat from the sun, which is essential for maintaining Earth's temperature and supporting life. It describes the greenhouse effect as a process where certain gases in the atmosphere absorb and retain heat, similar to how a glass greenhouse retains warmth.
supports.snippet: The Sun's energy is radiated in all directions in the form of photons, or packets of solar energy. ... How do the greenhouse gases trap heat? First they absorb ...

supports.title: FAQs • What are the “Greenhouse Effect” and “Greenhouse Gase
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, which is a fundamental aspect of the greenhouse effect.
supports.snippet: Thus, greenhouse gases trap heat within the surface-troposphere system. This is called the greenhouse effect. (Definition courtesy of IPCC AR4.) Climate ...

supports.title: Greenhouse effect - Understanding Global Change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly explains that greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere trap heat from the sun, which keeps the Earth's surface warmer than it would be without them, thus supporting the claim.
supports.snippet: Altogether, this cycle of absorption and re-radiation by greenhouse gases impedes the loss of heat from our atmosphere to space, creating the greenhouse effect.

supports.title: The Greenhouse Effect - UCAR Center for Science Education
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly explains that greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere trap heat from the sun, which keeps the planet warmer than it would be without them. This process is directly compared to how a glass greenhouse retains heat, confirming the claim about greenhouse gases trapping heat and energy from the Sun.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect causes some of this energy to be waylaid in the atmosphere, absorbed and released by greenhouse gases.

supports.title: What Are Greenhouse Gases and Why Do They Matter - Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases trap heat and slow heat loss into space, which supports the claim that they absorb heat and energy from the Sun.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases (GHGs) are a category of gases that absorb heat energy emitted from the planet's surface and they remain in Earth's atmosphere for a long time.

supports.title: What is the greenhouse effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that greenhouse gases trap heat and slow heat loss into space, which is a key aspect of the greenhouse effect.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is the process through which heat is trapped near Earth's surface by substances known as 'greenhouse gases.'

claim_reports.claim_text: Human-produced gases can have bad effects on the planet, including changing the climate and weather.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that human-produced gases negatively affect the planet by driving climate change and altering weather patterns. Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and the U.S. Energy Information Administration, confirm that activities like burning fossil fuels and deforestation increase greenhouse gas concentrations, leading to significant environmental impacts.

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation, are significantly increasing greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, which is driving climate change and altering weather patterns.
supports.snippet: By adding more carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, people are amplifying the natural greenhouse effect, causing global temperature to rise. According to ...

supports.title: Greenhouse gases' effect on climate - U.S. Energy Information ... - EIA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how human-produced greenhouse gases trap heat in the atmosphere, leading to climate change and alterations in weather patterns, which aligns with the claim about the negative effects of these gases on the planet.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases warm the planet​​ Rising temperatures may produce changes in precipitation patterns, storm severity, and sea level. Collectively ...

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation, are significantly increasing greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, which in turn is driving climate change and altering weather patterns.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is essential to life on Earth, but human-made emissions in the atmosphere are trapping and slowing heat loss to space.

supports.title: What Is the Greenhouse Effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, have significantly increased greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, which trap heat and contribute to climate change. This aligns with the claim that human-produced gases can negatively affect the planet's climate and weather.
supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere trap some of the heat from the sun. It prevents the heat from escaping back into space at night. This ...

supports.title: Heat-Trapping Pollution - Climate Central
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human-produced gases, particularly carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide, significantly contribute to climate change by enhancing the greenhouse effect, which traps heat in the atmosphere and leads to global warming.
supports.snippet: Carbon dioxide accounts for about 75% of global human-caused greenhouse gas emissions and has contributed the most to cumulative warming.

claim_reports.claim_text: Instruments can take snapshots of different gases in the atmosphere at a given time.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that various instruments, such as UCATS, COSPEC, and INSTEP, are capable of measuring different atmospheric gases simultaneously, supporting the claim.

supports.title: Greenhouse Gas Concentrations - Graphing Tool | NOAA Climate.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the capabilities of the UCATS instrument, which is designed to measure various atmospheric trace gases, confirming that instruments can indeed take snapshots of different gases in the atmosphere at a given time.
supports.snippet: The Interactive Data Visualization tool gives users a way to explore the abundance of different gases at more than 200 sampling sites around the world.

supports.title: Methods to measure gas and water vary depending upon the level ...
supports.evidence_summary: The article describes how instruments like COSPEC or DOAS spectrometers can measure specific gases, such as sulfur dioxide, in the atmosphere by scanning across a plume, which supports the claim that instruments can take snapshots of different gases at a given time.
supports.snippet: A COSPEC or DOAS spectrometer measures the amount of sulfur dioxide in a plume cross-section by transecting beneath a plume or scanning across it.

supports.title: Atmospheric Composition and Dynamics Instruments at Ames - NASA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that instruments like the INSTEP monitors can measure a variety of trace gases in the atmosphere, confirming that instruments can indeed take snapshots of different gases at a given time.
supports.snippet: The INSTEP monitors measure a variety of trace gases (CH4, HCHO, CO ... to O3 vertical-flux measurements using the eddy covariance technique.

supports.title: How Do You Measure Greenhouse Gases? | NIST

supports.snippet: CRDS instruments pull an air sample into a small chamber whose ends comprise two or more mirrors that have been finely polished and designed to ...

supports.title: A New Instrumented Airborne Platform for Atmospheric Research in
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the capabilities of the UCATS instrument, which is designed to measure various atmospheric trace gases, confirming that instruments can indeed take snapshots of different gases in the atmosphere at a given time.
supports.snippet: Including the AirCore in the Alpha Jet instrument suite will allow us to make measurements of carbon dioxide and methane up to 14.5 km—the Alpha Jet ceiling. ...

supports.title: UAS Chromatograph for Atmospheric Trace Species (UCATS) - AMT
supports.evidence_summary: The UCATS instrument is designed to measure various atmospheric trace gases, confirming that instruments can indeed take snapshots of different gases in the atmosphere at a given time.
supports.snippet: UCATS (the UAS Chromatograph for Atmospheric Trace Species) was designed and built for observations of important atmospheric trace gases from unmanned aircraft ...

claim_reports.claim_text: They study the impacts of crop growth on the atmosphere by analyzing fertilizer use.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the impacts of fertilizer use on crop growth and atmospheric conditions. While two high-reliability sources support the claim by linking nitrogen fertilizer use to enhanced crop growth and its atmospheric effects, three other high-reliability sources indicate that while fertilizers are essential, their environmental impacts, including air pollution and health concerns, complicate the relationship.

supports.title: How Climate Change Will Affect Plants
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how elevated CO2 levels can enhance plant growth and photosynthesis, but it also highlights the importance of nitrogen availability for sustained productivity, indicating that fertilizer use (which provides nitrogen) is crucial for maximizing the benefits of increased CO2 on crop growth.
supports.snippet: Rising levels of CO2 in the atmosphere drive an increase in plant photosynthesis—an effect known as the carbon fertilization effect. New ...

supports.title: The impact of nitrogen Fertilizer application on air Pollution
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the relationship between nitrogen fertilizer use and its impact on air pollution, specifically mentioning that nitrogen fertilizers applied to crops like rice and corn significantly increase PM2.5 concentrations, indicating a direct link between fertilizer use and atmospheric effects.
supports.snippet: Nitrogen fertilizers applied to rice and corn significantly increase PM2.5 concentration, while the pollution effect of nitrogen fertilizers on wheat is ...

mixed.title: Fertilizers and Human Health—A Systematic Review of the ...
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses the use of fertilizers in agriculture and their potential impacts on human health and the environment, indicating that while fertilizers are essential for crop growth, their application can lead to contamination of air, soil, and water, which may affect atmospheric conditions.
mixed.snippet: Fertilizers are an essential tool for soil management, but their use may result in an increase in contamination of soils, air, and water either ...

mixed.title: The Nutrient Challenge of Sustainable Fertilizer Management - USDA
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses the role of fertilizers in agriculture and their potential impacts on human health and the environment, indicating that while fertilizers are essential for crop growth, their effects on atmospheric conditions and health outcomes are complex and not fully understood.
mixed.snippet: Eutrophication is a process where fertilizer stimulates dense marine and fresh water plant growth, which can lead to the death of animal life ...

mixed.title: Sources and Solutions: Agriculture | US EPA
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses how elevated CO2 levels can enhance plant growth through increased photosynthesis, but it also highlights the importance of nitrogen availability for sustained productivity, which relates to fertilizer use in agriculture.
mixed.snippet: Agriculture can contribute to nutrient pollution when fertilizer use, animal manure and soil erosion are not managed responsibly.

claim_reports.claim_text: Eric's team collects air samples using special tools, including on airplanes.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that Eric's team collects air samples using specialized tools on airplanes, specifically mentioning airborne air samplers for capturing environmental DNA (eDNA) and other airborne analyses.

supports.title: Eric A. Kort – Home for Kort Research Group
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that Eric's team collects air samples using specialized hardware systems on airplanes, demonstrating their capability to gather airborne environmental DNA (eDNA) from various sources during aerial surveys.
supports.snippet: In the Kort group, our research is focused on understanding atmospheric composition and how it dynamically changes in response to human and natural forces.

claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that instruments are designed to measure atmospheric contents, similar to weather stations. claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence supports the claim regarding emissions from landfills and vehicles, as highlighted by the high-reliability sources discussing greenhouse gas emissions from these sectors. However, there are also unclear aspects regarding the extent of research on emissions from power plants and the overall measurement practices, as indicated by several other high-reliability sources that do not directly confirm the claim.

claim_reports.claim_text: The atmosphere is a mix of gases that surrounds our planet.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the atmosphere is a mix of gases, primarily nitrogen (78%) and oxygen (21%), as confirmed by the high-reliability source from the 'Earth's Atmosphere - The Driver of Climate'.

supports.title: Earth's Atmosphere - The Driver of Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the atmosphere is primarily composed of a mixture of gases, specifically nitrogen (78%) and oxygen (21%), along with trace amounts of other gases, which supports the claim.
supports.snippet: Earth's relatively thin atmosphere primarily consists of a mixture of nitrogen (78%) and oxygen (21%) gases. The remaining 1% contains several inactive gases.

transcript_data.text: [Music] [Music] we can think of the atmosphere as a mix of all sorts of gases that surrounds our planet some gases that humans produce can have bad effects on the planet including changing the climate and weather many of the human produced gases are called greenhouse gases these are gases that trap heat and energy from the Sun hi my name is Eric I'm an atmospheric scientist I study climate and greenhouse gases my group's research we really try to understand what's impact in the atmosphere and how that impacts climate Eric and his team study the atmosphere and measure the levels of gases that make it up including greenhouse gases the goals are to better understand where harmful gases are coming from but first they have to collect gases in the atmosphere and to do this they collect samples of air using special tools our instruments are designed to measure the contents of the atmosphere much like weather station would measure wind or rainfall or snowfall our instruments are designed to measure the molecules the components of the air that were actually in these instruments are able to take snapshots of the amount of different gases in the atmosphere at a given time which helps scientists investigate sources of greenhouse gases but since Eric and his team are thinking about the atmosphere they have an interesting approach to collecting their samples we have instrumentation that will put in different places sometimes we'll put it on an airplane and we'll actually fly the airplane around to different regions that were interested in studying the sources will collect air into inlets on the side of the airplane and actually measure it on instruments in the airplane by collecting samples in flight they are able to identify different emission sources that may not be measurable on the ground pretty cool but how does collecting air above the ground tell us about what is happening on the ground we can think about it this bees fly around from flower to flower as they fly pollen gets attached to them if we looked at a bee after a day of flying around we would be able to tell where it had been by looking at the types of pollen it collected Eric and his team are kind of like bees they fly around collecting samples of air and the samples are able to tell us about what is in the air they spend a lot of time flying and collecting samples over farms for this project we very much want to understand the impacts of how we grow our crops on the atmosphere so in order to grow crops you need to plant seeds you might put quite a lot of fertilizer down a lot of the nutrients from fertilizer going to the growing of the crops but not all of the nutrients make their way into the crops and the number of them are lost to the atmosphere by focusing on flying over farms they are able to tell if the fertilizers that farmers are using are good or bad for the atmosphere as we get towards answers we can help inform farmers on what our optimal practices to have them both get their best crop yields but minimize the losses to the atmosphere but their research doesn't just stop at farms they also fly over cities and other areas or fly downwind of cities to try to understand how much is being emitted from all the cars and vehicles in the city how much is coming out of landfills and power plants this research is important because in order to understand how the atmosphere is changing we have to understand what is making it change this research helps us determine where the problem is so we can fix it but don't let just the scientist do it all themselves you can help reduce your impact on the earth too so if one is concerned about what impacts you have on the atmosphere there are different actions that can be taken the most important thing is to simply be cognizant and aware of what you're doing being aware of subtle things even light bulbs on leaving the TV on when you're not watching it all of those small things do add up but there's also simply power being aware of the problem and then collective action that can come out of that do you want to be a scientist like Eric and his team try making your own sampling device [Music]
